The '''MoveOn.org ad controversy''' began when the U.S. [[Opposition to the Iraq War#Opposition in the United States|anti-war]] [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] [[advocacy group]] [[MoveOn.org]] published a full-page ad in ''[[The New York Times]]'' on September 10, 2007, accusing General [[David H. Petraeus]] of "[[cooking the books]] for the [[George W. Bush Administration|White House]]". The [[newspaper advertisement|ad]] also labeled him "General Betray Us".<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.abcnews.go.com/Politics/Decision2008/story?id=3581727&page=1 ABC News: Ad Against Petraeus Strikes a Nerve<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The organization created the ad in response to Petraeus' [[Report to Congress on the Situation in Iraq]]. MoveOn hosted pages on its website about the ad and their reasons behind it from 2007 to June 23, 2010. On June 23, 2010, after President Obama nominated General Petraeus to be the new top U.S. and NATO commander in Afghanistan (taking over the position from retiring General [[Stanley A. McChrystal|Stanley McChrystal]]), MoveOn erased these webpages and any reference to them from its website.<ref name=removes>{{cite news|url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/moveon-org-removes-general-betray-us-ad-in-response-to-petraeus-appointment/|publisher=[[Mediaite]]|title=MoveOn.org Removes "General Betray Us" Ad In Response To Petraeus Appointment|first=Jon|last=Bershad|date=June 24, 2010|accessdate=June 28, 2010}}</ref>
== Contents ==
===Arguments=== The ad<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071009170409/http://pol.moveon.org/petraeus.html]</ref> argued: *"Every independent report on the [[2007 in Iraq|ground situation in Iraq]] shows that the [[Iraqi troop surge of 2007|surge strategy]] has failed." ::The group later cited the [[GAO]],<ref>[http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d071222t.pdf]</ref> [[National Intelligence Estimate|NIE]],<ref>[http://www.politico.com/pdf/PPM44_070823iraq_nie_-_kj's_-_08-23-07.pdf]</ref> and Jones<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.csis.org/isf.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071004225311/http://media.csis.org/isf.pdf |archivedate=2007-10-04 |df= }}</ref> reports published for [[United States Congress|Congress]] around the same time as Petraeus' report. ''[[USA Today]]'' compared the four reports' findings.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2007-09-10-iraq-compare_N.htm "Comparing four views on Iraq situation"] by [[Jim Michaels]] in ''[[USA Today]]'' on September 9, 2007</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' also did so.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/ref/world/20070910_REPORTS_GRAPHIC.html | work=The New York Times | date=September 10, 2007 | accessdate=May 13, 2010}}</ref> The group referred to an [[Associated Press]] study finding that the civilian death toll in [[2007 in Iraq|August 2007]] was the second highest since the surge began. The study found as well that "monthly death tolls began to decline after the [[Operation Law and Order|new security plan]] was launched" and that "Deaths went down in [[Baghdad]] during August".<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20543737/ "At least 1,809 Iraqi civilians killed in August"] on [[MSNBC]]</ref> The group also referred to a ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' article stating that "the U.S. troop increase has had little effect."<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-violence1sep01,0,3069115.story "Iraqi civilian deaths climb again"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013204348/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-violence1sep01,0,3069115.story |date=October 13, 2008 }}</ref>
*"Yet the General claims a reduction in violence. That’s because, according to the [[New York Times]], [[the Pentagon]] has adopted a bizarre formula for keeping tabs on violence. For example, deaths by [[car bombs]] don’t count." ::The group later referred to an editorial<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/07/opinion/07krugman.html?_r=1&oref=slogin | work=The New York Times | first=Paul | last=Krugman | title=Time to Take a Stand | date=September 7, 2007}}</ref> by [[American liberalism|liberal]] [[Op-Ed|columnist]] [[Paul Krugman]]. ''[[The Washington Post]]'' has stated that Petraeus' report included data about [[car bombing|car bombs]].<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news| url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/fact-checker/2007/09/general_betray_us.html | work=The Washington Post | accessdate=May 13, 2010 | title=General Betray Us?}}</ref>
*"The Washington Post reported that [[assassinations]] only count if you're shot in the back of the head -- not the front." :: ''[[The Washington Post]]'' article [[anonymous sourcing|anonymously quoted]] a senior [[United States Intelligence Community|intelligence official]] in [[Washington D.C.|Washington]] commenting on U.S. military data. The official stated that "If a bullet went through the back of the head, it's [[sectarianism|sectarian]]" but that "If it went through the front, it's criminal."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/05/AR2007090502466.html "Experts Doubt Drop In Violence in Iraq"]</ref> According to ''[[The Washington Post]]'', the [[MNF-I]] says that they make no distinction among the possible points of impact on the head.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
*"According to news reports, there have been more civilian deaths and more American soldier deaths in the past three months than in any other summer we’ve been there." ::The group later cited an [[Associated Press]] story stating that "This year’s U.S. troop buildup has succeeded in bringing violence in [[Baghdad]] down from peak levels, but the death toll from [[sectarianism|sectarian]] attacks around the country is running nearly double the pace from a year ago." The story also stated that "The U.S. military did not get all the additional American forces into Iraq until June 15, so it would be premature to draw a final statistical picture of the effect of the added troops."<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20440397/ "Violence appears to be shifting from Baghdad"] on [[MSNBC]]</ref> The group also cited an [[NPR]] article quoting former [[United States Army|Army]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] [http://www.douglasmacgregor.com/ Doug MacGregor] calling Petraeus' statistics "an illusion created by the [[George W. Bush Administration|White House]]". The article concluded by stating that "So is the surge working? The short answer is that no one can know for certain because statistics only tell a small part of the story."<ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=14198105 NPR: Statistics the Weapon of Choice in Surge Debate<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
*"We'll hear of neighborhoods where violence has decreased. But we won't hear that those neighborhoods have been [[ethnically cleansed]]." :: The group later cited a ''[[Newsweek]]'' story stating that "When Gen. David Petraeus goes before Congress next week to report on the progress of the surge, he may cite a decline in [[Iraqi insurgency (2003–11)|insurgent]] attacks in [[Baghdad]] as one marker of success. In fact, part of the reason behind the decline is how far the [[Shiite]] [[Private militias in Iraq|militias]]' cleansing of [[Baghdad]] has progressed: they've essentially won."<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20546328/site/newsweek "Baghdad's New Owners"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070903202552/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20546328/site/newsweek |date=September 3, 2007 }}</ref>
*"Iraq is mired in an unwinnable [[sectarianism|religious]] [[Civil war in Iraq (2006-07)|civil war]]." *"General Petraeus has actually said American troops will need to stay in Iraq for as long as ten years." ::The group later referred to a statement by [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] [[United States House|Congresswoman]] [[Jan Schakowsky]].<ref>[http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/rep.-schakowsky-petraeus-hints-at-decade-long-iraq-presence-2007-08-10.html TheHill.com - Rep. Schakowsky: Petraeus hints at decade-long Iraq presence<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The [[nonpartisan]] website [[Factcheck.org]] criticized previous ads that state that Petraeus supports leaving troops in Iraq for ten more years<ref>[http://www.factcheck.org/elections-2008/liberal_lobby_lacks_context.html FactCheck.org: Liberal Lobby Lacks Context<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930011135/http://www.factcheck.org/elections-2008/liberal_lobby_lacks_context.html |date=September 30, 2007 }}</ref> because Petraeus had only said, during a [[BBC News]] interview, that "the average [[counter-insurgency]] is somewhere around a 9- or a 10- year endeavor" in reference to [[The Troubles]] in [[Northern Ireland]].<ref name=autogenerated2 />
===Criticism=== ''[[The Washington Post|The Washington Post's]]'' "Fact Checker" stated that the General's report of "sharply declining Iraqi casualty rates is certainly open to analysis, debate, and challenge" but that "MoveOn.org does not provide adequate factual support for its larger assertion that Petraeus is 'constantly at war with the facts' and is 'cooking the books' for the White House".<ref name=autogenerated2 />
== Controversies ==
=== Payment controversy === ''[[The New York Times]]'' initially charged [[MoveOn.org]] $65,000 for the ad using its "standby rate." ''[[The Washington Post]]'' has stated that the full one-time rate is $142,000 for an ad receiving guaranteed placement on a specific day.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/23/AR2007092300752_pf.html "New York Times Says It Violated Policies Over MoveOn Ad"], By Howard Kurtz, ''[[The Washington Post]]'', September 24, 2007, p. A8</ref> ''Times'' [[Ombudsman#News ombudsman|public editor]] and [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winner [[Clark Hoyt]] later stated in an [[editorial]] that the organization was mistakenly charged a rate to which it was not entitled under the newspaper's policies.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/23/opinion/23pubed.html?n=Top/Opinion/The%20Public%20Editor "Betraying Its Own Best Interests"], by Clark Hoyt, ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 23, 2007</ref> Moveon.org repaid the difference to the ''Times'' on September 25, 2007.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/26/us/26moveon.html?ex=1348459200&en=27c42c4c5a49bc84&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss | work=The New York Times | title=MoveOn Pays The Times $77,508 for Ad Cost | first=Katharine Q. | last=Seelye | date=September 26, 2007 | accessdate=May 13, 2010}}</ref> ''[[The New York Post]]'' quoted a ''Times'' [[public relations]] director saying the full one-time rate was $182,000, an additional $40,000 above what has been paid back.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/09132007/news/nationalnews/times_gives_lefties_a_hefty_di.htm | work=New York Post | title=Times Gives Lefties A Hefty Discount For 'Betray Us' Ad | first=CHARLES HURT | last=Bureau | date=September 13, 2007}}</ref>
[[Fox News]] stated: : Catherine Mathis, vice president of corporate communication at ''the Times'', said she could not discuss specific advertisers, but said the rate for a special advocacy, full-page, black and white, standby ad is $64,575. At that rate, an advertiser can request that an ad run on a specific date, but cannot be guaranteed such placement.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,296745,00.html | work=Fox News | title=Pro-Bush Group Airs Ads Denouncing Liberal Anti-Petraeus Ad | date=September 14, 2007}}</ref>
[[American Conservatism|Conservative]] [[columnist]] [[George Will]] argued that "the paper made a huge and patently illegal contribution to MoveOn.org's issue advocacy ad." He also stated that "''The Times''' performance in this matter confirms an axiom: There can be unseemly exposure of mind as well as of body."<ref>[http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2007/09/sauce_for_the_times.html "All the Hubris Fit to Print"] at [[RealClearPolitics]]</ref>
=== Copyright controversy === Google and MoveOn were accused of selective adherence to trademark law for removing ads from [[Google Adwords]] for Maine Senator [[Susan Collins]], citing infringement of MoveOn trademarks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,301267,00.html |work=Fox News |title=Sen. Susan Collins' Web Ads Run Up Against Google, MoveOn.org |date=October 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020102731/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,301267,00.html |archivedate=October 20, 2007 }}</ref> <ref>[http://googlepublicpolicy.blogspot.com/2007/10/our-advertising-policies-and-political.html Google Public Policy Blog: Our advertising policies and political speech<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' stated on October 15, 2007 that the "left-leaning political advocacy group, MoveOn.org, is backing down" and will allow Google to show the ads. "We don't want to support a policy that denies people freedom of expression," Moveon.org communications director Jennifer Lindenauer said.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/politics/onlinerights/news/2007/10/moveon |work=Wired |title=MoveOn.org Reverses: Allows Critical Ads on Google |date=October 15, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724044820/http://www.wired.com/politics/onlinerights/news/2007/10/moveon |archivedate=July 24, 2008 }}</ref>
== Response ==
===Political response=== [[Connecticut for Lieberman|Independent Democratic]] [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Joe Lieberman]], [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Tony Snow]], and several [[2008 Republican presidential candidates|Republican presidential candidates]] criticized the ad.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2007/09/romney_bashes_m.html | work=The Boston Globe | title=Republicans bash MoveOn.org over anti-Petraeus ad | first=Foon | last=Rhee | date=September 10, 2007}}</ref> [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] called the ad "disgusting."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/09/21/politics/washingtonpost/main3284062.shtml |work=CBS News |title=MoveOn Unfazed By Furor Over Ad, Washington Post: Liberal Group Presses On Despite Senate Resolution Denouncing Petraeus Ad - CBS News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016103404/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/09/21/politics/washingtonpost/main3284062.shtml |archivedate=October 16, 2007 }} </ref> [[United States Republican Party|Republican]] [[2008 Republican presidential candidates|presidential candidate]] [[Rudy Giuliani]] called it "character assassination on an American general who is putting his life at risk."<ref>https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070916/ap_on_el_pr/giuliani_clinton{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[John Kerry]] also criticized the ad.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2007/09/10/kerry-moveonorg-is-over-the-top/ | work=CNN | title=Kerry: MoveOn.org is 'over the top' | accessdate=May 13, 2010 | date=September 10, 2007}}</ref> [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] [[2008 Democratic presidential candidates|presidential candidate]] [[Joe Biden]] said on ''[[Fox News Sunday]]'', "They went, in that one instance, I think, overboard. But the point they were trying to make was still valid."<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,296957,00.html Transcript: Sen. Joe Biden on 'FOX News Sunday']</ref> Democratic presidential candidate [[Hillary Clinton]] said on ''[[Meet The Press]]'', "I don't condone anything like that, and I have voted against those who would impugn the patriotism and the service of the people who wear the uniform of our country".<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20941413/ ‘Meet the Press’ transcript for Sept. 23, 2007]</ref>
Several other Democratic Senators and [[United States House of Representatives|Representatives]] distanced themselves from the ad.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/POLITICS/09/10/petraeus.moveon/index.html | work=CNN | title=GOP calls on top Senate Dem to condemn anti-Petraeus ad - CNN.com | date=September 10, 2007 | accessdate=May 13, 2010}}</ref> Democratic [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] said "I would have preferred that they not do such an ad."<ref>[http://www6.lexisnexis.com/publisher/EndUser?Action=UserDisplayFullDocument&orgId=574&topicId=100007216&docId=l:670862827&start=34 ABC News Transcript] of ''[[World News with Charles Gibson]]'' on September 14</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' has stated that "Democrats acknowledge that the MoveOn advertisement was a distraction and illustrated the difficulties of working with [[modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] [[interest group|advocacy groups]]".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9501E0D9103AF931A1575AC0A9619C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=NEWS ANALYSIS; As Bills to End War Stumble in Congress, Partisan Din Swells | first=Carl | last=Hulse | date=September 22, 2007 | accessdate=May 13, 2010}}</ref>
Former President [[Bill Clinton]] criticized what he called the "disingenuous" "feigned outrage" of the Republicans on [[CNN|CNN's]] [[The Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer|The Situation Room]].<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vFzs_qCEGxY September 28 Video of Bill Clinton] on [[CNN]]</ref> [[Minnesota]] [[Minnesota United States Senate election, 2008|Senatorial candidate]] [[Al Franken]] argued in a ''[[Star Tribune]]'' editorial "It is, of course, ridiculous that the United States Senate spent a day debating and voting on a resolution condemning an advertisement while our troops remained in Iraq, fighting a war with no end."<ref>[http://www.startribune.com/562/story/1445784.html Al Franken: Hyper (and hypo)critical<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011141109/http://www.startribune.com/562/story/1445784.html |date=October 11, 2007 }}</ref>
[[linguistics|Linguist]] [[George Lakoff]] argued that the "ad has raised vital questions that need a thorough and open discussion. The ad worked brilliantly to reveal, via its framing, an essential but previously hidden truth: the Bush Administration and its active supporters have betrayed the trust of the troops and the American people."<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/george-lakoff/whose-betrayal_b_64579.html "Whose Betrayal?"] on the ''[[Huffington Post]]''</ref> [[modern liberalism in the United States|Liberal]] [[blog]]ger [[Arianna Huffington]] argued that "Was the MoveOn ad blunt? Yes. Did it go for the [[wikt:jugular|jugular]]? No doubt. But while the way it chose to make its points can be debated, the accuracy of those points cannot."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/arianna-huffington/dept-of-misdirection-wi_b_64748.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Dept. of Misdirection: With Iraq a Disaster, GOP Goes Crazy Over a Newspaper Ad | date=March 28, 2008}}</ref> [[Opposition to the Iraq War#Opposition in the United States|Anti-war activist]] and [[Cindy Sheehan#Sheehan challenges Pelosi for U.S. House seat|Congressional candidate]] [[Cindy Sheehan]] stated that "I have often been critical of MoveOn.org, basically because I feel, for the most part that they support Democrats to the detriment of democracy... The occupation of Iraq is a disaster and I applaud MoveOn for moving a little closer to the true '[[Opposition to the Iraq War#Opposition in the United States|anti-war]]' movement and encourage them to come with us farther."<ref>[http://www.commondreams.org/archive/2007/09/21/3988/ "General Betray-Us and MoveOn.org"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080708222625/http://www.commondreams.org/archive/2007/09/21/3988/ |date=2008-07-08 }} in [[Common Dreams NewsCenter|commondreams.org]]</ref>
[[Council of Foreign Relations]] fellow [[Peter Beinart]] argued that "It is terribly unfortunate that MoveOn.org is essentially calling Petraeus a Republican hack, but it’s the logical result of the position the [[George W. Bush administration|Bush administration]] has put him in." Fellow [[Max Boot]] accused Moveon.org of "desperate attempts to besmirch one of the most admired soldiers in the entire American armed forces" and argued that the ad will "backfire".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cfr.org/publication/14191/cfr_fellows_respond_to_iraq_testimony.html |title="CFR Fellows Respond to Iraq Testimony" |access-date=2007-10-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208080126/http://www.cfr.org/publication/14191/cfr_fellows_respond_to_iraq_testimony.html |archive-date=2008-02-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Pete Hegseth, an Iraq War veteran and executive director of [[Vets for Freedom]], published an article in the ''[[Weekly Standard]]'' calling the ad "utterly shameful." He argued that "It shows contempt for America's military leadership, as well as for the troops who have confidence in him, as our fellow soldiers in Iraq certainly do."<ref>[http://www.weeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/014/091rhesh.asp "MoveOn.org Calls Petraeus a Traitor"]</ref> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine [[blog]]ger [[Joe Klein]] posted that "It is no small thing to accuse a military man of betraying his country. It is also palpably untrue in this case. Whoever cooked up this ad is guilty of a disgraceful act of malicious [[wikt:puerility|puerility]]." He also posted that "This is a distraction from the main event."<ref>[http://time-blog.com/swampland/2007/09/moveoninfantile.html "Moveon.Infantile"]</ref>
[[MoveOn.org]] stood by their ad, stating that the General "offered a twisted version of the truth designed to support prolonging the war" and that "the public needs to know that Petraeus is neither objective nor trustworthy when it comes to assessing progress in Iraq". The organization also stated that the ad had been targeted by a "concerted right-wing [[smear campaign]]".<ref>[http://pol.moveon.org/petraeus_ad.html MoveOn.org Political Action: Democracy in Action<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070917051756/http://pol.moveon.org/petraeus_ad.html |date=September 17, 2007 }}</ref> ''[[The Politico]]'' has stated that Moveon.org "welcomes the controversy." Eli Pariser has said, "Sometimes you have to call a spade a spade, even if it’s a respected general".<ref>[http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0907/5813.html "'Betray Us' ad unites GOP, distracts Dems"]</ref> They have since deleted all reference to the ad from their web site.
===Legislative response=== On September 20, the Senate passed an amendment by [[United States Republican Party|Republican]] [[John Cornyn]] of [[Texas]] designed to "strongly condemn personal attacks on the honor and integrity of General Petraeus". All 49 Republican Senators and 22 Democratic Senators voted in support.<ref>[https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=110&session=1&vote=00344 U.S. Senate: Legislation & Records Home > Votes > Roll Call Vote<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,297498,00.html | work=Fox News | title=Senate Votes to Condemn MoveOn for Ad Attacking General Petraeus | date=September 21, 2007}}</ref> [[2008 Democratic presidential candidates|Democratic Presidential candidates]] [[Hillary Clinton]] and [[Chris Dodd]] voted against the amendment while [[Barack Obama]] and [[Joseph Biden]] did not vote.<ref name=nyt20070921>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/21/us/politics/21moveon.html?ex=1348027200&en=f5adccb90d16a2ae&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss "Senate Approves Resolution Denouncing MoveOn.org Ad"] in ''[[The New York Times]]'' on September 21, 2007</ref> Obama issued a statement calling the resolution, put forward by Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, "a stunt. By not casting a vote, I registered my protest against these empty politics."<ref name=nyt20070921/> The [[United States House|House]] passed an amendment to a continuing budget resolution which condemned the ad "in the strongest terms" by a 341-79 vote on September 26.<ref>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/F?c110:2:./temp/~c110n1vzvQ:e27159: Search Results - THOMAS (Library of Congress)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |date=September 20, 2007|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/washington/2007-09-20-senate-condemn_N.htm|title=Senate Condemns "General Betray Us" Ad|}} </ref><ref name="housecondemns">{{cite news | last =Marre | first =Klaus | title =House overwhelmingly condemns MoveOn ad | publisher =The Hill | date =2007-09-26 | url =http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/house-overwhelmingly-condemns-moveon-ad-2007-09-26.html | accessdate = 2007-09-26 }}</ref>
[[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] Senator [[Barbara Boxer]] of [[California]] drafted a similar amendment on September 20. The text condemned the Petraeus ad as well as a 2002 ad<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tKFYpd0q9nE]</ref> attacking then-Senator [[Max Cleland]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] during the [[United States congressional elections, 2002|2002 midterm elections]] and the [[Swift Vets and POWs for Truth]] [[Swift Vets and POWs for Truth#Media activities|ads]] attacking [[John Kerry]] during the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 Presidential election]].<ref>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/F?r110:1:./temp/~r110haWWbZ:e0: The Verbal Senate Record]</ref> Democratic Senator [[Carl Levin]] of [[Michigan]] said, "They're all disgraceful ads and we ought to treat them the same way".<ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=14623512 NPR: Anger over 'Betray Us' Ad Simmers on Hill<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The vote was 50-47 in favor, but since 60 votes were required to pass it, the amendment did not carry.<ref>[https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=110&session=1&vote=00343 U.S. Senate: Legislation & Records Home > Votes > Roll Call Vote<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote on September 20 that "Democrats blamed the group [[MoveOn.org]] for giving moderate Republicans a ready excuse for staying with Bush and for giving Bush and his supporters a way to divert attention away from the war".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/20/AR2007092001005.html?nav=hcmodule | work=The Washington Post | title=MoveOn Unmoved By Furor Over Ad Targeting Petraeus | first=Perry | last=Bacon Jr | date=September 21, 2007 | accessdate=May 13, 2010}}</ref> Eli Pariser, executive director of MoveOn.org Political Action, stated that "It is unconscionable and outrageous that instead of doing the people's work and ending this war, Congress chooses meaningless and distracting gestures.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/POLITICS/09/26/petraeus.moveon.ap/index.html |work=CNN |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209063242/http://www.cnn.com/2007/POLITICS/09/26/petraeus.moveon.ap/index.html |archivedate=December 9, 2007 }}</ref>
===Popular response=== A [[Rasmussen Reports]] survey found that 23% of Americans approve of the ad while 58% disapprove.<ref>[http://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/23_approve_of_moveon_org_petraeus_ad_58_disapprove Rasmussen Reports: The most comprehensive public opinion coverage ever provided for a mid-term election<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[The Economist]]'' stated on September 27 that "the group had raised $500,000 the day the Senate voted, its biggest one-day fundraising total all year. Over four days, in the midst of the row, it took in $1.6m[illion]."<ref>[http://www.economist.com/world/na/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9867661 "An ad too far"] in ''[[The Economist]]''</ref>
===Counter-ads=== [[2008 Republican presidential candidates|Republican presidential candidate]] [[Rudy Giuliani]] ran his own full-page ad<ref>See http://www.nysun.com/pics/62696_main_large.jpg</ref> in ''[[The New York Times]]'' on September 14.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/13/AR2007091302379.html | work=The Washington Post | title=Giuliani Plans Full-Page Ad Defending Petraeus | date=September 14, 2007 | accessdate=May 13, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/14/us/politics/14paper.html?_r=1&ref=politics&oref=slogin | work=The New York Times | title=Angered by an Antiwar Ad, Giuliani Seeks Equal Space | first=Katharine Q. | last=Seelye | date=September 14, 2007 | accessdate=May 13, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/09/17/politics/main3268035.shtml?source=RSSattr=HOME_3268035 | work=CBS News | title=Rudy Blasts Hillary Again Over MoveOn Ad | date=September 17, 2007}}</ref> Giuliani asked for and received a similar reduced fee as Moveon.org, paying $65,000.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2007/09/14/giuliani_slams_times_over_anti_petraeus_ad/ | work=The Boston Globe | title=Giuliani slams Times over anti-Petraeus ad | date=September 14, 2007 | first1=Katharine Q. | last1=Seelye}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/wn_report/2007/09/15/2007-09-15_general_petraeus_ad_nets_giuliani_big_bu.html | location=New York | work=Daily News | title=General Petraeus ad nets Giuliani big bucks from donors | date=September 15, 2007 | first=David | last=Saltonstall}}</ref> [[American conservatism|Conservative]] [[nonprofit]] [[lobbying]] [[interest group|organization]] [[Freedom's Watch]] created two video ads in response to MoveOn.org's ad.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ck18N3-4szk Freedom's Watch - Move On]</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RNPpy2DDrjU&mode=related&search= Freedom's Watch - Condemn]</ref><ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/09/13/politics/main3259934.shtml "New TV Ad Slams MoveOn.org"]</ref> On September 24, Freedom's Watch ran a full-page ad<ref>[http://bp0.blogger.com/_L6pDyjqqsvY/Rvcv0t9Z5vI/AAAAAAAAHl4/A7IHdjNYYoQ/s1600-h/freedom%27s+watch+iran+nyt+ad.JPG]</ref> in ''The New York Times'' attacking former Iranian President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] — calling him a "[[terrorism|terrorist]]". The ad asserted that Ahmadinejad "has supported attacks on our soldiers and our allies".<ref>[http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0907/6078.html "'Anti-MoveOn' claims first successes"]</ref>
===Removal=== MoveOn hosted pages on its website about the ad and their reasons behind it from 2007 to June 23, 2010. On June 23, 2010, MoveOn erased these webpages and any reference to them from its website. The change took place in the aftermath of President Obama's nomination of Petraeus to be the new top U.S. and NATO commander in Afghanistan upon General [[Stanley McChrystal]]'s retirement. Commentator Jon Bershad of [[Mediaite]] stated, "Since MoveOn is an advocacy group with no claims to unbiased content, there’s nothing unethical about scrubbing the site."<ref name=removes/>

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:⅜.jpg|thumb|200px|Painting by Muhanna Al-Durra]] --> {{Infobox artist | name = Muhanna Durra | image = مهنا دره.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1938 | birth_place =[[Amman]], [[Jordan]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Jordanian | training = [[George Aleef]], Jordan; Academy of Fine Arts, Rome (1958) | movement = [[Orientalism|Orientalist themes]]; [[Cubism]]; abstract art | known_for = Pioneer of Jordanian art movement, introduced cubism to Jordanian art community | influenced by = [[George Aleef]]; William Hallowin | influenced = Princess [[Wijdan Ali]]; Nawal Abdallah | awards = Al-Hussein Decoration | works = }} '''Muhanna Durra''' ({{lang-ar|مهنا دره}}), {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[Order of the Star of Jordan|OSJ]]}}, is a Jordanian painter widely regarded as a pioneer of the Jordanian Arts Movement and for being the first to introduce [[Cubism]] and [[abstract art]] into the Jordanian visual arts community. He is a professor at the Faculty of Fine Art and Design at [[University of Jordan]] and serves as the President of the [[Jordan Association of Fine Arts]].
== Life and career == Born in [[Amman]], [[Jordan]] in 1938 to a [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] father and a Turkish mother,<ref>"Myhana Al Durra" in ''Guide to Jordanian Culture,'' Online: http://www.bourse-des-voyages.com/jordanie/guide-culture-peintres-muhanna-al-durra.php</ref> Al-Dura was raised in a striking red hilltop villa in downtown Amman. The house is only a few blocks away from Amman's popular tourist attraction, the Roman amphitheater, and is commonly believed to rest atop an ancient Roman cemetery. As a child, spooky folklore about his neighborhood sparked a fascination with ghouls and "ignited fantasy in what was beyond the observable, physical world."<ref name="colors">{{cite book|last=Zuhur|first=Sherifa|title=Colors of enchantment: theater, dance, music and the visual arts of the Middle East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MOVPaLXjjsAC&pg=PA377&dq=Muhanna+Durra&hl=en&ei=4h4cTbKaJM2r8AbgrfCOCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Muhanna%20Durra&f=false|accessdate=30 December 2010|year=2001|publisher=American Univ. in Cairo Press|page=377}}</ref>
A notoriously rebellious youth with a penchant for drawing, he was sent by his father to study art with George Allief (also known as ''[[George Aleef]]''), a former Russian officer with the Tsarist army. Allief taught him the basics of watercolor, drawing and painting, and the European understanding of perspective. These lessons with Allief marked the young artist's transition from childhood drawing to the disciplined work of a professional artist. According to Dura's memoirs, Allief taught his students to meticuoulsy render a matchbox as an exercise in perspective.<ref>Mejcher-Atassi, S. and Schwartz, J.P., ''Archives, Museums and Collecting Practices in the Modern Arab World,'' Routledge, 2016, p.175</ref>
Following the formative years with Allief, the young Muhanna met Dutch painter, William Hallowin, who introduced him to Rembrandt and the Dutch school which sparked an obsession with the power of light. In 1954, he was sent to the [[Accademia di Belle Arti di Roma|Academy of Fine Arts in Rome]] to become the first Jordanian to receive a formal art education.<ref>"Muhanna Durra," in ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Vol. 2, Jonathan M. Bloom and Sheila S. Blair (eds), Oxford University Press, 2009, p.39</ref> He claims to have been disillusioned by the academy and committed himself to studying the classics through art in museums and churches. After graduating in 1958, Durra returned to Amman to teach history of art at the Teachers' Training College. In 1964, Durra established the Fine Arts Section at the Department of Culture and Art, Amman, and then established the Jordan Institute of Fine Arts in 1970. <ref>Mejcher-Atassi, S. and Schwartz, J.P., ''Archives, Museums and Collecting Practices in the Modern Arab World,'' Routledge, 2016, pp 175-76</ref>
Between 1960 and 1970, Al-Durra returned to Rome, where he experimented with abstraction and cubism. In 1970, he returned to Jordan to receive the Kawkab Decoration from King Hussein. <ref>"Muhanna Al Durra," ''University of Jordan Newsletter,'' October, 2017, <Online:http://ju.edu.jo/Lists/NewsLetter/Disp_form.aspx?ID=1418&Issue=October%202017&order=10></ref> Around that time, Durra established an art studio; the first Jordanian to establish an art studio to teach local students.<ref>Zuhur. S., ''Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music, and the Visual Arts of the Middle East,'' American University in Cairo Press, 2001, p. 377</ref> Among his notable students was the Princess [[Wijdan Ali]] who is best known for her attempts to revive the traditions of Islamic art.<ref>Hashem Talham, G., ''Historical Dictionary of Women in the Middle East and North Africa,'' Rowman & Littlefield, 2013 p. 24; Zuhur. S., ''Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music, and the Visual Arts of the Middle East,'' American University in Cairo Press, 2001, pp 377-78 </ref> Another student was Nawal Abdallah, who is one of the leading lights of Jordan's contemporary arts scene.<ref>Teller, M., "A Hit List of Jordanian Artists" in ''Jordan,'' Rough Guides, 2002, p. 425</ref>
==Work==
Durra is best known for his portraits and also for the way he treated shifting masses of colour.<ref>Teller, M., ''Jordan,'' Rough Guides, 2002, p. 425</ref> He is also acknowledged as the first artist to introduce cubism and abstract art to the Jordanian arts community. <ref>"Muhanna Al Durra," ''University of Jordan Newsletter,'' October, 2017, <Online:http://ju.edu.jo/Lists/NewsLetter/Disp_form.aspx?ID=1418&Issue=October%202017&order=10></ref>
'''Select list of paintings'''
* ''Blue Man Árabe,'' 1966 * ''Cubista Paisaje Urbano,'' 1966 * ''Portrait of Two Women,'' 1975 * ''Composition No. 3,'' oil on canvas, 75 X 95cm, 1977 <ref>Ali, W., ''Modern Islamic Art: Development and Continuity,'' University of Florida Press, 1997, p. 99</ref> * ''Autumn Dew,'' 1981 * ''Old Salti Woman,'' date unknown
==Honours and recognition==
Durra served as a diplomat in Italy, Tunisia, Egypt and later Russia, as Ambassador to the Arab League in Moscow.<ref>Leonov, L., ''The Library Syndrome,'' Walter de Gruyter, 1999, p. 201</ref>
In 2002 the Postal Authorities of Jordan issued a 200 fils postage stamp in honor of Mohanna Durra displaying one of his paintings.
In November 2006 the Ministry of Culture named an art gallery after Muhanna Durra, and held a national symposium about his art with the participation of prominent Jordanian artists and critics.
Other awards include:<ref>Rogers, S., "Muhanna Dura" in ''Mathaf Encyclopedia of Modern Art and the Modern World,'' http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org.qa/en/bios/Pages/Mohanna-Durra.aspx</ref>
* 1965 Decorated Knight of the Holy [[Order of St. Sylvester]] by [[Pope Paul VI]] * 1970 [[Order of the Star of Jordan]] by [[King Hussein]] * 1977 The first State Appreciation Award for his contribution to the cultural development of Jordan * 1978 Golden Medal of the Italian Ministry of Cultural Heritage * 1980 Golden Pioneer Medal and Appreciation Award of the Union of Arab Artists * 1992 Elected active member of the International Informatization Academy * 2006 [[Order of the Star of Italian Solidarity]] * 2008 Distinction of Al-Hussein Decoration from his Majesty King Abdullah II of Jordan (First Order)
==Exhibitions== Durra held numerous solo exhibitions in Rome, Florence, the USSR, various Arab and European capitals, Washington D.C., Plazzo Venezia, the 1988 Venice Biennale Exhibition, and the Fine Arts National Museum of Valletta, Malta. He later held solo exhibitions in Moscow, Saint Petersburg, the Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts and the Austrian Parliament Central Hall in Vienna.{{cn|date=October 2017}} In 2000, "Muhanna Forever: Pioneer of Modern Art in Jordan" was exhibited at the Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts and in 2006, he had a solo show at Lines Gallery, Amman, Jordan.<ref>''Mathaf Encyclopedia of Modern Art and the Modern World,'' [Muhanna Durra -Exhibitions, Online: http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org.qa/en/bios/Pages/Mohanna-Durra.aspx</ref>
Durra's work is represented in various national and international collections, including that of the Vatican, the Imperial Court of Japan, the President of the Philippines, Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau of Canada, David Rockefeller, The Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts, Fannie Mae Bank in Washington, D.C., Bonn City Hall, Washington, D.C. City Hall, the University of San Francisco, Georgetown University, as well as several Jordanian institutes.

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} '''Nicky Imber''' ([[Vienna]] 1920 -1996) was a multidisciplinary Jewish artist best known for his sculptures on Jewish themes. Grand nephew of [[Naftali Herz Imber]], author of the Israeli national anthem '[[Hatikva]]'. [[File:Nicky Imber working on head.jpg|thumb|250px|Nicky Imber working on sculpture]] After escaping the Nazi concentration camp in [[Dachau]],The Daily Journal Friday September 22, 1972 he pledged to dedicate his art to perpetuating the memory of the Holocaust. Among his more famous works are "[[The Hope (Imber)|The Hope]]" and "The Love of Torah". His work can be seen around the world, in [[Northern Israel]], the [[United States]], and the Venezuelan Museum of Natural History in Caracas. == Biography== Nicky Imber was born in [[Vienna]], Austria. During his studies at the Academy of Arts in Vienna, he drew anti-Nazi caricatures for Jewish student publications.Meir Hareuveni, Ma'ariv newspaper, September 22, 1981 After several thwarted attempts by the family to leave Vienna, in 1938, in the wake of the '[[Anschluss]]', Imber was deported to [[Dachau]]. Witnessing the murders of family and friends, he plotted his escape. Using skills he had learned in art school, he made a face mask out of bread and sand, stole a Nazi soldier's uniform and walked out the front gate unnoticed.Letter from [[Carmiel]],1981 Yad Vashem Archives In 1940, he boarded a ship headed to [[Haifa]]. The ship's passengers were refused entry by the British mandatory authorities and imprisoned in a detention camp in [[Mauritius]]. In 1943, Imber worked out a deal with the authorities for his release by joining the British Army, serving as a war artist and a dental assistant in East Africa. After the war, he opened an art school in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]], and worked as a photographer and a safari guide. In 1949 to 1954, he lived in [[Venezuela]], where he was contracted to do an East African [[Diorama]] series. The National Museum added an entire wing to display it.Ve Venezuela Vol.2 No.56 April–May 1975
During this period he got married and had a daughter Raquel, who accompanied and assisted him. [[File:Nicky Imber with one of the sculptures of the prehistoric animals.jpg|thumb|Nicky Imber with one of his prehistoric animal sculptures]] In 1959, Imber was commissioned to create sculptures and dioramas for the Haifa Prehistory Museum at Gan Ha-em in [[Haifa]], Israel. In 1960 he returned to Venezuela to restaured the Phelps series of Dioramas for the Museum in Caracas.Münstersche Zeitung Friday August 22, 1980 Between 1961 and 1971 he travelled extensively around Europe and after establishing an international name for himself, returned to the United States. In New York he became famous for his realistic oil paintings of portraits of [[Aga Khan]], [[Tyrone Power]], [[Ava Gardner]], [[David Ben-Gurion]], [[Golda Meir]], [[Sir Richard Burton]] and [[Simon Bolivar]].The Sun Reporter Tuesday July 31, 1973 Returning to Venezuela in 1976, Imber created huge sculptures of prehistoric animals, forming one of the world's largest historical animal parks. During this period he also created realistic sculptures of famous Venezuelans for the country's National Hall of Fame.El Nacional, Caracas, Thursday, April 22, 1976
In 1978, Imber spent three years designing and building a Holocaust memorial park at the entrance to the city of [[Karmiel]] located in the Galilee, entitled 'From Holocaust to Resurrection.' Imber also established animal theme playgrounds around the city. [[File:Nicky Imber building "Hope" in Carmiel, Israel.JPG|thumb|Nicky Imber building "Hope" in Carmiel, Israel]] In the 1980s, Imber established residence in Karmiel, Israel. In Israel he was inspired to create highly emotional, life like collections. Nicky Imber died in 1996 in Vienna, Austria. ==See also== *[[Visual arts in Israel]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{official website|http://nicky-imber.com/}} * Diana Lerner, Imberman dream of "City of Dreams", Ma'ariv, December 24, 1959 {{DEFAULTSORT:Imber, Nicky}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:1996 deaths]] [[Category:Artists from Vienna]] [[Category:Jewish artists]] [[Category:Dachau concentration camp survivors]]

{{dablink|For the band from Boston, see [[November Group (band)]].}} [[File:Cawén, Alvar - Members of The November Group - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Alvar Cawén]], ''Members of the November Group'' (1921) currentlocation: [[EMMA – Espoo Museum of Modern Art]]]] The '''November Group''' ({{lang-de|Novembergruppe}}) was a group of German [[expressionism|expressionist]] [[artist]]s and [[Expressionist architecture|architects]]. Formed on 3 December 1918, they took their name from the month of the [[German Revolution]].
The group was led by [[Max Pechstein]] and [[César Klein]]. Linked less by their styles of art than by shared [[socialist]] values, the group campaigned for radical artists to have a greater say in such issues as the organisation of art schools, and new laws around the arts. The group merged in December 1918 with [[Arbeitsrat für Kunst]] ([[Workers Council]] of the arts - or 'The Art Soviet').
==Weimar Republic== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-S29554, Berliner Kunstausstellung, Vorbereitung.jpg|thumb|Preparation for the opening of the {{Interlanguage link multi|Great Berlin Art Exhibition|de}}, June 1924]]
The artists of the November group described themselves as radical and revolutionary. Their work, like that of the similar [[Arbeitsrat für Kunst]], aimed to support a socialist revolution in Germany. A key objective of the group was the union of art and the people. Furthermore, the group tried to influence public and cultural aspects of society.
In 1921, artists from the left wing of the November Group called for an end to the "bourgeois development" of the artists. The declaration was signed by [[Otto Dix]], [[George Grosz]], [[Raoul Hausmann]], [[John Heartfield]], [[Hannah Höch]], [[Rudolf Schlichter]] and [[Georg Scholz]].
In 1922, the decentralised November Group restructured away from a conglomeration of local groups and became part of the "Cartel of advanced artistic groups in Germany" (Kartell fortschrittlicher Künstlergruppen in Deutschland).
A synthesis of styles is a characteristic of the group, often referred to as cubo-futo-expressionism, (Kubofutoexpressionismus) but really the group had quite disparate output which makes classification rather problematic.
As well as painters, there were many artists from other disciplines such as architecture and music. The musicians became one of the driving forces under their leader [[Max Butting]] (later replaced by [[Hans Heinz Stuckenschmidt]]).
The November Group held regular art festivals, costume parties, studio visits, literary and musical events.
==Founding members== The group was initially founded mainly by painters [[Max Pechstein]], [[Georg Tappert]], [[César Klein]], [[Moriz Melzer]] and [[Heinrich Richter]]. At the first meeting on 3.12.1918 they were joined by [[Karl Jakob Hirsch]], [[Bernhard Hasler]], [[Richard Janthur]], [[Rudolf Bauer (artist)|Rudolf Bauer]], [[Bruno Krauskopf]], [[Otto Freundlich]], [[Wilhelm Schmid (painter)|Wilhelm Schmid]], the sculptor [[Rudolf Belling]] and the architect [[Erich Mendelsohn]]. From this group the first working committee were drawn.
==Members== A definitive list of all the members of the group is rather difficult to establish due to a lack of early documentation. However, one of the exhibition catalogues was reprinted in 1925 with the following list of names: {{Refbegin|3}} *[[Lou Albert-Lasard]] *[[George Antheil]] *Rudolf Ausleger *[[Herbert Behrens-Hangeler]] *[[Rudolf Belling]] *[[Hans Brass]] *Max Butting *[[Carel Willink]] *[[Heinrich Maria Davringhausen]] *[[Walter Dexel]] *[[Christof Drexel]] *[[Hanns Eisler]] *[[Viking Eggeling]] *[[Conrad Felixmüller]] *[[Lyonel Feininger]] *[[Otto Freundlich]] *[[Paul Goesch]] *[[Otto Griebel]] *[[Gustav Havemann]] *[[Karl Jakob Hirsch]] *Wilhelm Heckrot *Hans Siebert von Heister *Oswald Herzog *[[Hannah Höch]] *Lothar Homeyer *[[Jascha Horenstein]] *[[Philipp Jarnach]] *[[Walter Kampmann]] *[[Wassily Kandinsky]] *Bernhard Klein *[[César Klein]] *Fritz Klein *Issai Kulvianski *[[Otto Lange]] *[[El Lissitzky]] * [[Thilo Maatsch]] *[[Ewald Mataré]] *Moriz Melzer *[[Carlo Mense]] *[[Hilla von Rebay]] *[[Ludwig Mies van der Rohe]] *[[Otto Möller (Maler)|Otto Möller]] *Rudolf Möller *[[Georg Muche]] *Albert Mueller *[[Laszlo Peri]] *[[Felix Petyrek]] *Enrico Prampolini *Kurt Hermann Rosenberg *[[Hans Scharoun]] *[[Paul Schmolling]] *[[Arthur Segal (painter)|Arthur Segal]] *[[Rudolf Schlichter]] *[[Wilhelm Schmid (painter)|Wilhelm Schmid]] *Heinrich Stegemann *[[Hans Heinz Stuckenschmidt]] *[[Georg Tappert]] *[[Bruno Taut]] *[[Heinz Tiessen]] *[[Wladimir Rudolfowitsch Vogel]] *[[Kurt Weill]] *[[Gert Wollheim]] *[[Stefan Wolpe]] *Niko Wassiliew *[[Walter Spies]].<ref>Helga Kliemann: ''Die Novembergruppe.''
